tbnpy.cpt module¶

class tbnpy.cpt.Cpt(childs, parents=[], C=[], p=[], Cs=[], ps=[], evidence=[], device='cpu')[source]¶

Bases: object

Defines the conditional probability Tensor (CPT). CPT is based on the same concept as CPM in Ref: Byun et al. (2019). Matrix-based Bayesian Network for efficient memory storage and flexible inference. Reliability Engineering & System Safety, 185, 533-545. The only different is it’s based on tensor operation, using pytorch.

childs¶

list of instances of Variable objects.

Type:

list

parents¶

list of instances of Variable objects.

Type:

list

C¶

event matrix.

Type:

array_like

p¶

probability vector for the events of corresponding rows in C.

Type:

array_like

Cs¶

event matrix of samples.

Type:

array_like

ps¶

sampling probability vector for the events of corresponding rows in Cs. NOTE: log probabilities are stored in ps.

Type:

array_like

Notes

C and p have the same number of rows. Cs and ps have the same number of rows.

property C¶
property Cs¶
property childs¶
property device¶
property evidence¶
expand_and_check_compatibility(C_binary, samples)[source]¶

C_binary: (n_event, n_var, max_state) samples: (n_sample, n_parents, max_par_state) p: (n_event,) OR (n_event, 1)

Returns:

(n_sample, n_event) with incompatible event-sample pairs set to zero.

Return type:

p_exp

Notes

Cb_exp: (n_event, n_sample, n_var, max_global_state) Sm_exp: (n_event, n_sample, n_parents, max_global_state) mask: (n_sample, n_event) 1 if compatible, 0 otherwise

expand_and_check_compatibility_all(C_binary, samples_binary)[source]¶

Generic compatibility check that treats ALL variables uniformly. Unlike expand_and_check_compatibility, this function does not distinguish between child and parent variables.

C_binary: (n_event, n_vars, max_state) samples_binary: (n_sample, n_vars, max_state)

Returns:

(n_sample, n_event)

event probabilities with incompatible pairs zeroed.

Return type:

p_exp

log_prob(Cs, batch_size=100000)[source]¶

Computes log P(sample | parents) for each row of Cs. Cs is arranged in the same order as self.variables = childs + parents.

log_prob_evidence(Cs_par, batch_size=100000)[source]¶

Compute log P(evidence | parents(samples)) for each parent sample.

Cs_par can be:

(N_samples, n_parents) or (n_evi, N_samples, n_parents) # evidence exists for parents too

Returns:

(N_samples,) tensor of log probabilities

Return type:

log_probs

property p¶
property parents¶
property ps¶
sample(n_sample=None, Cs_pars=None, batch_size=100000)[source]¶

Samples from this CPT.

Case 1: No parent nodes

-> n_sample must be provided -> returns (n_sample, n_childs)

Case 2: With parent nodes

-> Cs_pars provided as composite parent samples: (n_samples, n_parents) -> returns (n_samples, n_childs)

Uses batching to avoid constructing large tensors at once.

sample_evidence(Cs_pars, batch_size=100000)[source]¶

Vectorized sampling given aligned parent evidence.

Cs_pars: (n_evi, n_samples, n_parents)

Returns:

(n_evi, n_samples, n_childs + n_parents) ps_out: (n_evi, n_samples)

Return type:

Cs_out

sample_from_p_exp(p_exp)[source]¶

p_exp: (n_samples, n_events) probability matrix (not normalized)

Returns:

(n_samples, n_childs) sampled child composite states event_idx: (n_samples,) sampled event indices

Return type:

Cs

Notes

C: (n_events, n_vars) stored in self.C n_childs: number of child variables
